5/ August 13:  Fetch AI encountered a security breach with their official Discord channel. The perpetrator gained unauthorized server access using an admin account.

4/ August 10:  Fireblocks disclosed a series of vulnerabilities collectively referred to as "BitForge" and classified as "Zero Day" vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities could affect various popular crypto wallets using Multi-Party Computation (MPC) technology.

3/ August 9:  Earning Farm was compromised, suffering a reentrancy attack that led to a loss of 286 ETH (~$530K). Subsequently, the attacker transferred 292.64 ETH to a specific EOA address.  The Twitter account of the cryptocurrency venture capital firm Blockchain Capital was‚Ä¶ https://t.co/uOE0fYz3vK

2/ August 8:  Steadefi faced an attack attributed to private key leakage, resulting in a $1.1M setback. Though assets were converted to ETH and moved to Ethereum, the team was able to recover around $540K. The attacker also transferred 400 ETH via Tornado Cash.  Indian‚Ä¶ https://t.co/KAotD6PSAs

5/ Due to the increased _assetPriceCached in balanceOf, the 84 zETH was inflated to 221 zETH.  The attacker swapped the inflated 221 zETH (LP) for 389 $ETH, repaid the 6,811 ETH flash loan and fees, profiting 26 ETH in the end.  All stolen funds were sent into Tornado Cash. https://t.co/ls9n9Rhu71

4/ The zETH (LP) value calculation depends on both the CRV price and the exchange rate calculated from the CRV and ETH balances in the sEthFraxEthCurveConvex contract.  The attacker manipulated the $CRV price and $CRV balance, increasing the final _assetPriceCached. https://t.co/Jk31BmG1Oq

3/ Swap 11 $ETH for 35,293 $CRV and transferred it into the sEthFraxEthCurveConvex contract to manipulate the CRV balance.  Use 406 ETH to repeatedly swap for CRV in the wETH/CRV pool, pumping the CRV price about 10x. https://t.co/8aecEme0Qt

Bit shifting is usually not the most intuitive concept to grasp, but we hope the analogy has simplified the topic for you!  Thanks to @bytes032 for the guest post ü´°
Why do that?  Just like in a library, space is precious, and so is time.  By using this shorthand, you save space in your logbook and also make it faster to jot down the note.
How?  By simply type-casting `history` to `uint112`.  W ignore the top 112 bits and only keep the lower 112 bits https://t.co/ft9JGS2gBs

Getting the books from the bottom shelf (`stakerStakedAtTime`)  Here, we use "magic glasses" that let us see only the bottom shelf  This makes the top shelf invisible.  This way, we focus solely on the newer books at the bottom. https://t.co/iVlZKrURIY

By performing a right shift (history >> 112), the upper 112 bits of the history are moved to the lower half.  This effectively isolates the top portion of the `history`  Then, casting it to uint112 keeps only these lower 112 bits (which originally were the top bits of `history`). https://t.co/v4f6s3dkNq

Getting the books from the top shelf (`stakerPrincipal`)  This is like looking only at the older books on the top shelf. We briefly remove the bottom shelf to only see the top shelf.  How? https://t.co/QvVAJcnadq

Imagine you have a bookshelf  -Top shelf for older books latestPrincipal -Bottom shelf for newer books latestStakedAtTime  Say you run a library  Every time someone borrows/returns books you make a note  A note has a unique number & details on which books were borrowed/returned https://t.co/3Zx5Yj5RQR

The purpose of this approach is to efficiently store two related pieces of data (`latestPrincipal` and `latestStakedAtTime`) as a single unit within the `history` data structure.  By packing these values together, the data can be stored, retrieved, and managed more efficiently.
The result is a `uint224` value with `latestPrincipal` in the top 112 bits and `latestStakedAtTime` in the bottom 112 bits.

uint224(uint112(latestStakedAtTime))  The value is first type-casted to `uint112`, then to `uint224`.  The bitwise OR operation `|` is used to combine the previously shifted `latestPrincipal` with `latestStakedAtTime`.

`(uint224(uint112(latestPrincipal)) << 112)`:  Here, the value is first type-casted to uint112`to ensure it fits within 112 bits.  It's then type-casted again to `uint224` to make it compatible for the left-shift operation.

s_checkpointId: This is a unique identifier for the record.  The use of `++` indicates that it's an auto-incrementing value.  Each time this code runs, `s_checkpointId` is incremented by one, ensuring a unique ID for every new record.
First things first, what is exactly "history.latest()"?  It's actually a checkpoint (identifier) for the latest principal/stakedAt time for the staker.  Let's drill deeper: https://t.co/7309ppO8iv

@RocketSwap_Labs @officer_cia That's it. Stay safe out there!   Follow @Immunefi for more #ImmunefiAnalysis content.
@RocketSwap_Labs For further reading about secure cryptocurrency storage strategies, we suggest checking out this comprehensive guide made by @officer_CIA (https://t.co/sXYNm24T9x).

@RocketSwap_Labs Another tip, if your wallet is recovered via an email and password combo, or phone number OTP, you may be susceptible to phishing attacks, sim swaps, and potential database breaches. We almost always recommend a paper or hardware wallet for this reason.

@RocketSwap_Labs If you are using your address to sign a message, be sure to check all the approvals and privileges that were given to this address. You can use websites such as https://t.co/mrXUZTMpA2 to revoke any useless approvals before signing any messages, which will help prevent misuse.

@RocketSwap_Labs Be sure to use use long passwords (10 characters more) with upper and lowercase letters, digits, and special symbols. Better yet, use a password manager (Chrome, Bitwarden, KeePass) to generated complicated passwords will make brute force attacks time-consuming, if not impossible https://t.co/nlKDK2glXd

@RocketSwap_Labs Next, set up strong passwords for all of your accounts to prevent brute force attacks. Hackers no longer sit around typing in passwords all day ‚Äî they use software that does this automatically.   For most people‚Äôs passwords, it can be just a few seconds to an hour:

@RocketSwap_Labs If you are using a separate device or computer for signing, an additional security measure is to ‚Äúair-gap‚Äù it. Don‚Äôt connect it to any USBs, wifi networks, bluetooth, ethernet cables etc.   Here's how to do this with an old smartphone or computer: https://t.co/WA6GnIMSvj

@RocketSwap_Labs If you have the technical knowhow, you can even use a virtual machine or sandbox environment. There are hundreds of methods, and thousands of reasons for hackers to try and get malware installed on your device, and so you should always be vigilant of what you download and open.

@RocketSwap_Labs Next, keep your computer safe from malware by screening downloaded files through a virus checker like https://t.co/7vAhJZQRcK before opening them. Better yet, use a whole separate computer just for signing messages, and don‚Äôt download or open any new files with it.

@RocketSwap_Labs You can also use an old-fashioned paper wallet: just write down your seed phrase on a piece of paper! Don‚Äôt forget to keep it somewhere hidden and safe. Make backups as well, in case you lose it.

@RocketSwap_Labs First of all, we suggest that you use a cold wallet: it can be something like a Ledger, or make your own. Here‚Äôs how to make one using a flash drive with at least 32GB of memory (https://t.co/Qx9cQEoOn2)

@RocketSwap_Labs Logically, if somebody has your seed phrase, they will be able to steal everything from your balance ‚Äì without needing any additional access to your phone, computer, or wallet interface. Once a hacker has your keys, your funds are as good as gone.  Now, let‚Äôs discuss prevention:

@RocketSwap_Labs One common misconception with crypto is that each token or coin is an individual digital item that moves from wallet-to-wallet. Instead, each wallet has an address to which a balance is assigned. This is controlled via a seed phrase or a private key kept by the owner.

@RocketSwap_Labs Ultimately, the attack was due to security issues with private key management.   Let‚Äôs discuss some secure methods and techniques that you can use to store your seed phrases more safely:

@RocketSwap_Labs According to the internal RocketSwap investigation, the team needed to use offchain transaction signing methods, which requires the transfer of important seed phrases through a server. The attacker obtained valuable keys by using a brute force attack on the server.

Line 115 - LT will check if the Enum accessed value is lower than it's max value, otherwise - REVERT in line 123 https://t.co/HusSku4muK

Here's how that check looks:  on the following transaction I called the function with 3 as an input, as for line 111 value 3 is on top of the stack Line 112 - EVM will push 1 (the max element value + 1) to the top of the stack Line 113 - DUP2 will place 3 in top of the stack https://t.co/YqVmUzqgdy
For example in the following contract, 0 can be used as an input the the call() function, however any value above 0 will result in revert https://t.co/evJlKzFgv1

2. Although Enums maximum potential value is 255, on runtime you can't exceed the expected Enum value, otherwise the execution will revert, in every access to the Enum the compiler will check that the specified value doesn't exceed the Enum max value

Two interesting facts about Solidity Enums: 1. Enums are compiled to uint8 which means you can't create an Enum with more than 255 values (good luck with that) otherwise the compiler will fail https://t.co/QJV0brYy9N

In conclusion, token contract implementations and behaviors may vary from project to project. To safeguard funds and transaction accuracy, it's recommended to have a deep understanding of the contract logic and conduct comprehensive testing before integrating any new tokens.
3. Regularly perform code audits and security checks to ensure system robustness and security.

2. Be aware that there are many token contracts in the market that do not adhere to the ERC20 standard. Before integrating new tokens, ensure a deep understanding and analysis of their contract code to ensure the correct deposit logic.
Recommended Actions:  1. When handling the logic of token deposits, rely not just on the success or failure of transactions but also on the actual return values from the token contract.

Specifically, when the LDO token contract executes a transfer operation with a quantity exceeding the user's actual holdings, it doesn't trigger the usual transaction rollback. Instead, it merely returns ‚Äúfalse‚Äù as the outcome rather than indicating a failure.

...repaying the flash loan and capping off the attack with a successful exit for the attacker.  Although the amount stolen is relatively small compared to the 100,000s or millions stolen in headlines, https://t.co/FevDDapzp9

When swapping FLOOR tokens to ETH, the attacker received the wETH gained from Uniswap in a separate account.  After receiving a callback from Uniswap, triggering the "uniswapV3SwapCallback()" function in the exploit contract, which sent FLOOR tokens to repay the swap,

Here's how it did that: The stolen FLOOR tokens were then swapped for wETH in the UniswapV3 pool via the "flash()" function. Then, the baton was passed to "uniswapV3SwapCallback()", which just handles executing the swap.

The attacker repeated this stake-unstake cycle exactly 17 times to get the mathematically optimal profit from the attack. After that, the last thing the ‚ÄòuniswapV3FlashCallBack()‚Äô function had to do was to repay the flash loan that funded the attack.

This function is important because it is used to calculate the "bounty" variable that was discussed earlier. "sFLOOR.rebase" returns a uint256 value which modifies the amount of FLOOR tokens to be sent back to the staker. https://t.co/DCEXQrItn0

Meanwhile, the "bounty" variable has been set to a value equal to zero.  Next, the attacker called the ‚Äòunstake()‚Äô function, which in turn triggered the rebase() function.  In this iteration, the "epoch.distribute" variable has been passed to "sFLOOR.rebase" function.

While calling the "rebase" function the first time, the attacker affected the "epoch.distribute" variable and set it to a nonzero value, which is equal to the FLOOR balance of the staking contract subtracted by the circulating supply of sFLOOR.
However, at this stage, the attacker has yet to make any profit at all ‚Äì all of this is just the preparation work for the actual exploit.

Here, the vulnerable rebase() function was called, which calculated a variable called "bounty", which will be used later. This variable is used to increase supply of sFLOOR, increasing staked balances relative to the amount of the bounty distributed by the end of epoch.

The vulnerability lies in a critical sub-function present in the "stake()", "unstake()", and "rebase()" functions.  In this first stage, the attacker began by staking FLOOR tokens via the Floor DAO staking contract using the "stake()" function.

...and the sFLOOR circulating supply.  If the combined balances of the exploit contract and the Floor Staking contract were higher than the sFLOOR circulating supply, then the exploit contract would stake and immediately unstake the FLOOR token.

This was a smart piece of code that could watch certain smart contracts, and alter its function based on their balances.  It looked at several things before executing its payload: the FLOOR balance of the exploit contract, the FLOOR balance of the Floor Staking contract,

As soon as the exploit contract received the flash loan, the second function, "uniswapV3FlashCallBack()", was triggered. This is the most complicated piece of the puzzle. The function also had a "while" loop which let it run exactly the right amount of times.

The first, "flash()", was the entry point of the attack. It made a flash loan of all available FLOOR tokens in the Uniswap V3 pool and then swapped all of the FLOOR tokens to ETH. https://t.co/5QloDFJcFC
In this transaction, the attacker called a function on their exploit contract and passed two arguments: 0 and 17.  The exploit itself consisted of three functions, which we'll get into shortly.

In order to understand this complicated, multi-step attack, we reverse-engineered the attacker‚Äôs exploit contract using @Dedaub‚Äôs decompiler.  The hack happened in this transaction: https://t.co/WgUaQg8nri

On 5th September 2023, @FloorDAO was attacked for ~$65k worth of FLOOR token, which the blackhat converted to ETH and sent to a mixer.  It was a very tricky exploit to execute and equally challenging to decipher.  Let‚Äôs try understand this hack in human-readable termsüëá https://t.co/Xz93GGCjeX

The SlowMist security team advises users that the ongoing BGP attack against Balancer is still in progress. It is recommended to temporarily refrain from visiting #Balancer 's website to avoid potential attacks.

7/ After @MistTrack_io analysis, the malicious addresses are as follows: 0x00006DEAcd9ad19dB3d81F8410EA2B45eA570000 0x645710Af050E26bB96e295bdfB75B4a878088d7E 0x0000626d6DC72989e3809920C67D01a7fe030000  https://t.co/2YLaMU4JCc
6/ Connecting a wallet will automatically check the balance and authorize phishing attempts and other actions. https://t.co/ZtAmvhFXi9
5/ After analysis, it has been determined that there is malicious JavaScript code in the frontend of https://t.co/CvCC40oeoc (https://t.co/1hXm02kYBl). https://t.co/xaQCAWgOXf
4/ Currently, when you visit https://t.co/H5HlPZgMAu, you will receive a #phishing security alert from CloudFlare. https://t.co/bQi7VO0gOV
3/ The HTTPS certificate has been replaced with the attacker's certificate. https://t.co/hj9PSnpUKY

2/ According to CloudFlare's records (https://t.co/t4NXIvhvdo), AS13335 is listed among the ASes (Autonomous Systems) that are currently experiencing BGP Origin Hijacking attacks. https://t.co/hwioempETy

1/ The domain balancer[.]fi's DNS resolution records (https://t.co/5sWAqiUM24) show that in the A records, there are two IP addresses: 104.21.37.47 and 172.67.203.244. Both of these IP addresses belong to the BGP AS number AS13335, which is associated with CloudFlare. https://t.co/xQX3AK0ngb

According to CloudFlare's BGP Origin Hijack-17957 data, ASNs (Autonomous System Numbers) in the list of victims include AS13335, to which balancer[.]fi belongs. Currently, accessing the website triggers a phishing security alert from CloudFlare.

4/ We expect this trend to shift again when markets recover. In the meantime, investors and projects alike should make securing their funds a top priority. CertiK offers a variety of services and resources that can help.

3/ Bear market conditions and low market liquidity likely explain this. Both suggest there is less money for hackers to steal, but also less incentive to negotiate than when incidents prove highly lucrative.
2/ Our findings between 2020 and September 2023 indicate the number of attempted negotiations is on the rise. However, as time passes hackers are stealing less and returning less.

1/ Different projects pursue different strategies when it comes to negotiations. Some are project driven, others are driven by the community, and some a combination of the two. White hats also play an increasing role.
